awd_titl_txt: RUI: Applications of 19F NMR spectroscopy to evaluate non-human bromodomain molecular recognition
awd_abstract_narration:
Scott Bur of Gustavus Adolphus College is supported by an award from the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Division of Chemistry to study the malaria-causing parasite Plasmodium falciparum.  The focus of the project is on gene-regulating proteins that contain a molecular recognition site known as the bromodomain.  Because of its unique molecular structure, the bromodomain is able to recognize specific molecular changes made to other proteins---histones---that are involved in packaging and storing DNA within the cell nucleus.  Histone modifications can strongly affect gene expression.  The bromodomain functions as a specialized "molecular detector" for such modifications. This research has implications for improving human health by developing potential treatments for parasitic infection and cancer.  Through this project, discovery-based research is incorporated within the curriculum of this primarily undergraduate institution (PUI).  Undergraduate students participating in the course activities gain experience in experimental design, state-of-the-art chemical techniques, and communicating their research to other scientists.  The skills are transferrable to the chemical job market. 

Little is known about the roles that specific epigenetic-regulator proteins play in regulating gene expression, especially in non-human systems.  One such regulatory protein, the Plasmodium falciparum homolog of General Control Non-repressed protein 5 (PfGCN5), is known to have an epigenetic regulatory role. This project is aimed at discovering the natural histone acetylation mark preferred by the PfGCN5 bromodomain, and identifying synthetic ligands that selectively disrupt the interaction of this domain with its natural ligand in the presence of other bromodomains.  NMR spectroscopy techniques are used to observe interactions of the PfGCN5 bromodomain with peptides that simulate histone tails. These histone tails, which contain specifically acetylated lysine residues, are produced using solid-phase peptide synthesis.  In the second part of the project, high-affinity synthetic ligands for PfGCN5 are being identified using a fragment-based ligand discovery strategy.  Fragments are translated into larger ligands with higher affinity using linking or growing strategies, and protein-fragment interactions are then assessed via in silico fragment docking experiments, PrOF NMR screening, and X-ray crystallographic analysis of the PfGCN5 bromodomain with a bound fragment.  This research provides a foundation for understanding the requirements of selective interactions between the bromodomain and acetylated histone, and molecular recognition events that are important for selectivity.  Structure-activity studies are embedded early in the undergraduate curriculum at Gustavus Adolphus College, providing undergraduate students with authentic research experiences and exposure to techniques for the production, isolation, and analysis of biomolecular polymers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on a particular subset of epigenetic regulators---gene-regulating proteins---that contain a molecular recognition site known as the bromodomain.  Because of its unique molecular structure, the bromodomain is able to recognize specific molecular modifications made to other proteins, called histones, that are involved in packaging and storing DNA within the cell nucleus.  Histone modifications can strongly affect downstream gene expression; the bromodomain functions as a specialized “molecular detector” for such modifications.  Little is known about the roles that specific epigenetic regulator proteins play in regulating gene expression in non-human organisms. This project sought to understand two fundamental questions of molecular recognition and regulation of gene expression involving the bromodomain of PfGCN5, a homolog of the human GCN5 protein found in the malarial causing parasite Plasmodium falciparum. Our primary question was "what are the natural histone acetylation marks read by the PfGCN5 bromodomain?" Secondary to this fundamental question is "what are the critical features of PfGCN5 bromodomain molecular recognition events?" 

 

Intellectual Merit

            To answer the first question, we purchased a microwave-assisted solid-phase peptide synthesizer to make short strings of amino acids that mimic the disordered tails of the histone proteins.  Using this solid-phase synthesis, we were able to synthesize and test about half of the known possible acetylation marks.  We used Protein-observed 19F (PrOF) Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) to measure the binding strength (Kd, the concentration where half of the protein is binding with the peptide) of each possible histone tail.  (NMR is a technique that uses the same technology as Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI), but helps us identify molecular structure rather than anatomical features.)  Although other reports suggested that we should measure a Kd of approximately 600 µM, the peptides we measure were all higher than about 2 mM (almost 10 times higher concentration than would be expected). We will continue to make and test more derivatives.

            To answer the second question, we first tested a library of molecules that were known to bind to human bromodomains using PrOF NMR.  This identified several unique molecular scaffolds that bound to the PfGCN5 bromodomain in the appropriate binding area.  We developed an undergraduate chemistry lab wherein each student in the lab section makes a different derivative and measures the binding using PrOF NMR.  To date, our best derivative binds with a Kd of about 90 µM, but none of them is selective for the PfGCN5 bromodomain over other bromodomains.

            Simultaneous with this work, we validated a computational method for measuring the binding interaction between the protein and a molecule "docked" in the binding area (a virtual screen).  We then screened approximately 1.5 million fragments (small molecules that resemble key parts - or fragments - of medicines) against the PfGCN5 bromodomain.  The 10,000 molecules that bound best were then virtually screened against all known human bromodomains to see if we could identify molecules that selected for the P Falciparum bromodomain but not affect the human bromodomains.  Using PrOF NMR to assess the binding strength, we confirmed one of the structures bound well to the PfGCN5 bromodomain but didn't appreciably bind to PCAF or CECR2 (human bromodomains that are known to be very close to PfGCN5 in structure).  We synthesized a small library of derivatives, and it became clear that PrOF NMR was no longer a sufficient technique to measure the binding. 

            We purchased a system that uses ALPHAscreen technology to measure the binding between a protein and a small molecule.  In this technique, if no small molecule is bound to the protein, flashing the mixture with a specific color of light will cause an energy absorption followed by emission of a different color light (fluorescence).  The brightness of the emitted color can be measured.  If a small molecule binds to the protein, the fluorescence is lost (no light is emitted).  The strength of the binding can be measured by comparing the intensity of the emitted light when various concentrations of small molecule are present.  Currently, our best-binding molecules have Kd values of approximately 40 µM, and PrOF NMR studies show that it does not appear to bind appreciably with PCAF or CECR2. 

 

Broader Impact

            A total of 16 undergraduate students worked on this project and were trained in basic synthetic organic chemistry techniques, isolation and characterization of small molecules, and basic biochemistry and molecular biology techniques for producing, isolating, and characterizing proteins with non-natural amino acids incorporated.  In addition to these sixteen students, over 100 additional students worked on the project through the undergraduate chemistry lab.  

            We have discovered a series of molecules that selectively binds the PfGCN5 bromodomain, though we are still searching for the native histone mark that this bromodomain binds. The PI was involved in one presentation at a national American Chemical Society (ACS) meeting and two regional ACS meeting.  Two publications have resulted from this project.
